children.subject:
Ya I agree. Grad school stress is real, and it's hard to console people on that, and it's true that a high GPA can look really nice on a resume, but the ROI of stressing on a high GPA is so low compared to the effects of stressing on GPA. I know people with around 3.0(and less) and they got interviews at all the competitive companies that seemingly reject low GPA students for high GPA students. These people had side projects from basic tutorials, did academic interning, and had a nicely formatted resume and that was it.

If someone doesn't want to go to grad school, GPA is basically useless. C's will get the degree at that point.

It’s not entirely Berkeley’s fault, but more like people’s. There is nothing wrong with having hard classes, but people go crazy over a bad grade. In reality, your grades do not even really matter. Now don’t get me wrong, you should still work hard and get the best grade you can. But in reality, there is no difference between getting an A or A-(or getting a B or B-). No one cares! Except only cap requirements for cs declaration. Your GPA matters(little bit, nothing too crazy) but if you have taken 10 courses, your grade in 11th will have a very slight effect on your gpa, so please keep calm. I assure everybody, your health, future goals are much more important than any grade you will get in any berkeley class.
Why would you have gone to those school in hindsight? What about this school makes it worse for you?

Good question, and I find that my experiences will not be perceived the same way as they might be by others, but I find that the level of difficulty is too high for my liking with regards to everything, be it academics, career fairs, joining clubs, becoming involved in research, TA-ing etc. I do understand that diamonds are made under pressure, but there is something as TOO much pressure, and Berkeley seems to have gone way beyond the level of pressure I would have liked to embrace. Yes, you might want to feel a little challenged, but when it becomes too challenging it can become overwhelming and that had been the case for me until I waved the white flag and told myself to just stop caring about anything besides my personal passion (which is not CS). Yet, I would have felt much happier at those places because I have high school peers studying in those places who are excelling, and while it's not easy to excel there, I know for a fact that if they can excel there I would have too. Here, I've realized I can't excel, it's just too damn hard.
I know quite a few peole who share your sentiments. How do you think Berkeley can remedy this?

It can't. Unless it literally became as selective for CS/EECS majors as those that it hopes to compete against, like MIT and Stanford. Basically limiting the number of admits right from the gate would help balance out the size of the classes, allow for more opportunities per person, would get rid of the GPA cap and allow for a decent amount of grade inflation. This would directly address just a few of my gripes with this school, but then I realize what I'm essentially saying is that if Berkeley became Stanford, it would be all good. But Berkeley will be Berkeley, it will never be Stanford, so that's that.

I'm not sure if Georgia Tech or UIUC have that much easier CS Programs than Berkeley. All colleges are meant to push to you to learn more, and that's how people grow. What exactly do you find so hard here that you "can't excel"? If it's just the strength of your peers, you will see that at all the top CS schools.

While I can’t speak for all schools, I’ve noticed many schools, including UIUC, MIT, UW, split their courses more often than Berkeley.

For example in operating systems, there is usually an intermediate course between 61c and 162 that teaches you a bit of OS before diving into the deep end.

70 is also often split into two, with the discrete math class covering more and the probability class being closer to the first half of 126.

I wonder if part of the rigor is the consequences making students dive down the deep end and learning so many topics in the span of a semester.

When it comes to academics, I will admit I haven't looked at the exams for those schools' course equivalents. I'm more or less extrapolating from what I do know about my peers and their work ethic / performance etc. in high school relative to mine, and I believe that if they could excel at those colleges then I could too. As for why I can't excel in other spheres, it's mostly because of the lack of opportunities per person here (not sure what that's like at those schools). But it's aight, I'm not about this competitiveness anymore. Now I'm pretty laid back, without a care in the world. Not like any of this matters in the long long run, if you catch my drift. Thanks Berkeley, for teaching me that much lol

I do agree in that I should have chosen UIUC, Gtech or UCLA, but hindsight is 20-20. I think I would have had a much better time in any of those places than I have had here. O well, you win some you lose some, and I have however come to terms with the fact that I just gotta take the L by having to come here, and focus on the next phase of my life so that I can end up in a better relative situation

Well I mean, I have plenty of friends who don't go to Cal, or a high ranking school, and they're getting same salary as we are. I feel like people see that and, if they are stressing at Cal, wonder why they even came here.

This fits exactly in the mind set described above of "doing CS for money, not for fun". This is the true reason we are so depressed and even think of this kind of questions. Berkeley is the best CS program you can find in world at a low cost and an average family background. You will find such variety of interesting courses where only top programs like MIT, CMU, Berkeley has. Many of my friends are at top 20 colleges but they even doesn't have undergraduate quantum computing or decent undergraduate ML classes. I felt so lucky that I didn't made that choice like them and came to Cal. At here we could become the future scientists and talk with Turing Award winners. You can have so many things to beyond a job and a number, why depressed?

I even highly doubt it's UCLA students who posted those on public forums. Got admission to both. My Berkeley admission letter is in an album in my parent's room. LA admission letter? I don't know but probably some random garbage can and never think about it for a minute.

They joke but if you let many choose they would still come to Cal again. While many people talk about how hard Berkeley EECS is, their effort will turn into reward reflected in Cal's reputation/starting salary in industry. I agree the workload for CS is hard for many underprivileged individuals, but many of my friends who came from a very good background complain a lot as well. To the latter, I would say they doesn't see the opportunities come with the challenges. And I found a depressing culture is here largely because people do CS for money, not for fun. This is very different from other elite CS programs. But Berkeley let everybody in, staff sacrificed a lot, disregard this problems brought by them. We should be grateful

Awesome, except I just want to add that no one has to "sacrifice their mental health". It's more like persevere to enhance your mental stability and stamina in order to succeed! I think the challenges push us to generate energy and strength in ourselves, mentally and emotionally, that we wouldn't have otherwise.

I agree with ya (original anon) but I think when people like OP refer to "toxic culture" they mean the comments about normalized depression, "our school going to ****" (their words), and overall high stress that you can find practically anywhere on Berkeley facebook groups and etc.

I think by toxicity, they really just mean that these negative (although maybe true) comments about the depressing, stress-inducing environment trigger other people to feel similarly. It's almost contagious. Like you might see someone say that Berkeley doesn't care about students' mental health and although you never given it a thought before or even agree, somehow that comment makes you feel not so good about being here.

Do you really believe that all those people are actually depressed? I feel like most of them just are spreading the rhetoric and complaining when they have a lot of work piled up. And I definitely agree with the 3rd anon that no has to sacrifice their mental health. There's certainly some level of stress with completing all the work on time, but it's good stress that helps you grow.

I mean I get the classes are hard and people can be depressed about their performance and competition, but in terms of a "toxic culture", I don't think Berkeley is anything of the sort. I define a toxic culture where your peers are actively trying to stop you from achieving your goals. In fact, I'd say Berkeley is SO competitive that it's almost the opposite of toxic. To gain a competitive edge in classes, people often result to pooling together notes, forming large study groups and overall just being really inclusive to anyone who wants to contribute. 

Of course there are going to be counterexamples, like people going in and deleting entire google docs of notes to gain a competitive advantage, but in my experience at Berkeley(Computer Science), people are generally welcoming. Also some of these nasty side effects just come with the territory of being the #1 public school(maybe), #1 in Computer Science, and top 5 in engineering as a whole. People come here to learn all they can and prepare themselves for their futures -not get easy A's.

I guess what I'm trying to say is that Berkeley's culture is what YOU make of it. You should think of Berkeley's course difficulty not as a disadvantage of attending Berkeley, but as a challenge, proof that you can tough it out with the top dogs and come out on top. Berkeley's international name recognition doesn't come from a reputation of being easy. Google recruiters don't actively seek out Berkeley graduates because Berkeley has easy courses. Those recruiters know you've gone through hell and back, tore out your hair during midterms, sacrificed your mental health to learn all you can. 

I agree Berkeley is a double edged sword of sorts, but which side of the sword you use in your quest is up to you.

history.content:
I just read a few reddit posts about Berkeley's toxic culture filled with people discussing how depressing the school is, and how tough the courses are. In addition, people constantly remarking about how toxic the school is, how depressed they are(in person, memes pages, etc), which apparently enhances this toxic culture. Complaints about dining hall food too.

Lots of people over the years have joked(or not) about how they should have chosen UCLA.

Thoughts?
history.subject: Toxic Culture At Berkeley
